awd_titl_txt: 3D Printing of Smart Structural Composites by Thermoelectric Extrusion with Molecular Precision
awd_abstract_narration:
A smart structural composite provides structural support with built-in sensing (temperature, pressure, flow and load) functionalities.  Recent advances in intelligent infrastructure and the proliferation of wearable gadgets and smart prosthetics have created a need for manufacturing affordable, customizable, and precise smart structural composites. Among current manufacturing methods, 3D printing can directly build customizable parts from computer models, but lack the ability to incorporate additives (such as piezoelectric nanoparticles) that provide sensing functionality. Most polymer-based 3D printing methods build parts by layer-by-layer deposition of a polymer extruded out of a nozzle above its melting temperature and have limited control of the polymer microstructure as it cools down. This leads to poor dimensional accuracy of 3D printed parts in comparison with parts fabricated from traditional manufacturing processes. This award supports fundamental research to create new knowledge in 3D printing and its application in healthcare, education, and engineering will foster new economic activity. This award also supports participation of women and underrepresented groups in engineering research and outreach efforts by the investigators with middle and high school students.

The objective of this research is to formulate relationships between an applied electric field during the extrusion of thermoplastic ionomer/piezoelectric composite and its resulting material properties (e.g., optical clarity, strength, piezoelectric strain coefficient, and interfacial adhesion between polymer matrix and nanoparticles). In a thermoplastic ionomer, the difference in polarity between the hydrocarbon chain and ionic group creates an electrostatic driving force and results in aggregation of ions. In this context, there exists a knowledge gap on the aggregation of ions in a thermoplastic ionomer above its melting temperature under the influence of an externally applied electric field. In order to understand how an electric field (greater than the electrostatic force of aggregation) applied to a mixture of thermoplastic ionomer/piezoelectric additive affects aggregation morphology (size, distribution in the matrix and around nanoscale additives), the research team will conduct experimental research and coarse-grained molecular dynamics simulations of a representative thermoplastic ionomer with piezoelectric additives (ethylene/methacrylic acid with PZT-5H and PVDF).
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
We have developed a novel additive manufacturing technique for 3D printing of smart structural composites that use simultaneous application of thermal and electrical fields. The smart structural composites contain PZT-5H particulates in a thermoplastic ionomer matrix and the application of electrical field to the polymer blend renders the PZT-5H particulates piezoelectric and uniformly distribute ionic aggregates in matrix. The PZT-5H particles impart mechanical sensing functionality and the a controlled distribution of ionic aggregates leads to higher Young's modulus and mechanical strengthof the thermoelectrically processed composite. The experimental work to develop process-structure-property relation ship were assisted by molecular dynamics simulations that used coarse-grained models to investigate the behavior or ionomers with particulate inclusions. The molecular dynamics simulations were designed to understand properties of ionomers, to allow for better control over fundamental mechanical properties in 3D printing. We first updated a prior simplified polymer model to better represent partially neutralized ionomers such as the ethylene-methacrylic acid (as opposed to prior models of regularly spaced, fully neutralized ionomers). We explored how neutralization and other factors impact the ionic aggregate morphology, known to be a key factor in the overall material properties. We then performed simulations using this model to focus on the impact of nanoparticles and of electric fields, as were included in the experimental systems of interest here. In considering interfacial adhesion of surfaces (a crucial factor in 3D printing), we found that the specific features of interfacial aggregate structure lead to variations in the dynamics and final amount of interfacial mixing (related to strength of adhesion). 

The funds from this project were used in the support of two doctoral thesis, one each in mechanical and chemical engineering and has led to 4 journal publications and 2 intellectual property disclosures (1 published patent pending and 1 provisional patent) till date. The knowledge gained from this research award will be integrated into an existing graduate course taught by the PI on polymer smart materials. 

We worked with the STEAM Factory at OSU, which has a facility in an underserved area of Columbus. We presented to the general public on three occasions about the molecular behavior of polymers and 3D printing. We are also working towards disseminating this research to middle- and high-school age students via scientific articles that reach a broader general audience and promote STEM education. 


Last Modified: 12/18/2018
Modified by: Vishnu Baba Sundaresan
